title: Semantic Diff Prompting for Video Understanding
description: Proposed Semantic Diff Prompting, a prompt-level method for Vision-Language Models that focuses on semantic changes between consecutive video frames.
highlights: Designed structured prompts to capture object state changes and motion events, reducing redundant frame-level descriptions
Built an experimental pipeline for frame extraction, caption generation, and offline metric evaluation without model fine-tuning
Evaluated the approach on short action videos, measuring token usage, lexical redundancy, and action-focused information density

title: Notification Urgency Classification
description: Built a supervised text classification system to categorize notifications as Urgent, Important, or Ignore using message content alone.
highlights: Designed an end-to-end ML pipeline with text normalization, TF-IDF feature extraction, and classical classifiers
Evaluated multiple models using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and confusion matrices
Identified linguistic patterns correlated with urgency through model analysis and error inspection

title: Echolin.AI – Deepfake Image Detection
description: Built an image forensics prototype for deepfake detection using CNN-based models and ensemble classification techniques.
highlights: Curated and preprocessed a large-scale dataset of real and synthetic images with augmentation pipelines
Evaluated model performance using accuracy, false-positive rate, and held-out test sets
Applied Grad-CAM visualizations to support qualitative inspection and interpretability
Designed a low-latency inference architecture using FastAPI with GPU-backed execution

title: RapidTriage AI – Emergency Care Prioritization
description: Built a triage classification prototype using structured and free-text clinical-style data to predict patient priority levels.
highlights: Developed preprocessing, embedding, and feature pipelines to support reproducible experiments and 20% faster training iterations
Improved macro-F1 by +0.12 through model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and class-imbalance handling
Applied probability calibration and error analysis to reduce overconfident predictions on minority classes
Simulated emergency department workflows using a dashboard-based prototype

title: NEUQuest – Student Event & Travel Companion App
description: Built an Android app using Firebase Realtime Database with authentication, maps, and push notifications.
highlights: Implemented offline caching and responsive layouts, achieving 90%+ Lighthouse performance and accessibility scores
Supported onboarding of 200+ users and tracked engagement metrics such as notification click-through rate
Reduced common support issues by adding in-app verification and deep-link flows

title: Husky Mingle – Campus Networking Platform
description: Designed and built a mobile-first campus networking platform supporting groups, projects, and real-time chat.
highlights: Implemented Firebase authentication and push notifications to support post-event engagement
Improved onboarding flow, reducing time-to-first-connection from 4.2 days to 1.6 days
Tracked engagement metrics during pilot usage, including increases in post-event connections

title: Course Scheduling Optimization
description: Modeled course scheduling conflicts as a graph-coloring problem and implemented Greedy and Welsh–Powell algorithms.
highlights: Reduced simulated scheduling conflicts by 40% and improved room utilization by 12%
Generated feasible schedules efficiently in practice, with typical datasets completing in under 2 seconds
Used as a teaching case in CS 5800 Algorithms to demonstrate practical applications of graph coloring

title: Impact of Online Images on Gender Bias
description: Analyzed a large-scale image-text dataset using computer vision features and text embeddings to study gender bias.
highlights: Developed bias metrics to compare gender-related signals in textual embeddings and image-derived representations
Conducted controlled online survey experiments to evaluate alignment between model outputs and human perceptions
Presented results at a class research symposium and contributed to follow-on research discussions

title: SPAMbase – Email/SMS Classification
description: Built a Naïve Bayes spam classifier using bag-of-words features (CountVectorizer) for email and SMS classification.
highlights: Evaluated model performance using precision, recall, ROC-AUC, and confusion matrices on a benchmark dataset
Reduced false negatives through threshold tuning, prior adjustment, and token filtering
Used as a baseline reference in later machine learning coursework
